author: magicking
content: I have dumb questions related to the deposit contract withdrawal commitment, the spec mention that the first byte of the hash of the withdrawal public key MUST BE replaced by the value of a prefix corresponding to a version number (https://github.com/ethereum/eth2.0-specs/blob/dev/specs/phase0/deposit-contract.md#withdrawal-credentials)

author: magicking
content: Why is it ok to lose precision over the generated hash of the public key?

author: magicking
content: What software part the version refer to (BLS, deposit-contract, ...) ?

author: jgm
content: It's not so much precision as address space.  31 bytes is still a decent sized space

author: magicking
content: I understand it's wide but if we accept one, why can't we accept more ðŸ™‚ ?

author: jgm
content: My *guess* is that this was an initial attempt at an address format.  For which this is as reasonable as anything else (48 bytes is too unwieldy when translated in to any sort of useful representation)

author: jgm
content: 31 bytes really is enough in terms of avoiding collisions

author: benjaminion
content: As it says, it's just a versioning thing. The 0x00 byte is the version number. If in future the withdrawal commitment calculation gets changed for any reason, then the version number will be used to indicate that. Eth1 manages just fine with 20 byte addresses; 31 bytes is waaay overkill for the withdrawal commitment.
